reasoning: The critique targets the post’s use of the “max speed” thought experiment and the author’s claim that low implied ceilings (e.g., <10×) are “implausible,” arguing this is more intuition/personal incredulity than a defended model. That point is relevant but not load-bearing for the overall position, since the post offers many other independent reasons to doubt transferring economy-wide CES substitutability estimates to AI R&D; so centrality is moderate. Within the attacked sub-argument, the critique does meaningfully weaken it: the author largely gestures at informal plausibility rather than deriving constraints or presenting a quantitative model linking abundant cognitive labor to a necessarily high ceiling under fixed compute. The critique is mostly correct and clear, with little extraneous material, and it focuses on a single issue. Overall impact on the full position is limited (strength×centrality modest).
title: The "max speed" thought experiment relies on intuition rather than formal derivation
